awd_titl_txt: EAGER: PPER: Collaborative: Cellphone-Enabled Water Citizen Science for Data and Knowledge Generation, and Sharing: WatCitSci
awd_abstract_narration:
This Water Citizen Science, "WatCitSci," project seeks to expand the capacity for water resource data collection by leveraging public participation in the efforts.  Novel, cell phone-based water quality sensors for cloudiness, acidity levels, dissolved oxygen concentration and surface water flow are being developed and deployed to citizen scientists.  These participants are then being deployed to gather data for making informed water management decisions in municipalities, agricultural areas, and other water-intensive sectors.  This project offers a platform and knowledge source for many future research, education and policy making efforts. Sharing new knowledge may also fuel novel approaches in assessing and projecting impacts of water use and allocation that affect all sections of society.  The development of citizen science tools will enhance community engagement on water quality engineering and research, specifically addressing challenges to our drinking-water systems and the safety of our water supplies.

The tools developed for WatCitSci include cellphone-based water quality sensors for turbidity, pH, and dissolved oxygen concentration and a particle tracking velocimetry tool for surface water flow quantification. These efforts, initiated at Missouri University of Science and Technology, make water quality assessment assessable to the citizenry, both economically and technologically. The project researchers use the approaches of the scientific method with hands-on, engaging activities to guide others in formulating research questions, conducting scientific experiments, collecting and analyzing water data, interpreting results and investigating community impacts.  The resultant WatCitSci citizen scientists provide deployable data collection to "critical control points" when and where water supply or water quality becomes an issue.  The data collection, computation and integration platforms can then be used in developing forecasting models to create a wide array of research opportunities. Future researchers will have increased ability to gather data on critical water issues at greater spatial and temporal resolution, particularly in urban communities. The objectives of the project are: 1) Humans in Advanced Networks - Developing advanced data collection and computation in cell phone-based platforms for rapid deployable citizen scientists; 2) Public awareness through integrated student/citizen science programs, bi-directional knowledge transfers and educational tools for classrooms and field education; 3) Integrated real-time data analysis information projection to stakeholders and decision-makers; and, 4) Assessing water attitudes, beliefs and quantifying public understanding of citizen science knowledge and beliefs via social media.

por.por_cntn:
Water is a critical component to human health and also a limiting resource to agricultural, energy production, and commerce. Our health, economies and social well-being are tightly interwoven with our water cycles, and we endeavored to develop a Water Citizen Science platform, WatCitSci, to increase knowledge or water importance in our local to global citizenry. New sensor technology was developed for rapid testing and linking to cellphone platforms for collecting and sharing data gathered. 

A new set of sensors and approaches were developed.  The open-source, inexpensive turbidimeter demonstrated comparable performance with respect to the commercial turbidimeter within the range of 0.06 to 1000 NTU.   The open-source nature with off-the-shelf components and simple instrumentation makes it easy to build by public, given proper tools are available. The proposed meter is designed for surface water quality determination, which usually has high turbidity compared to drinking water. This inexpensive, open-source turbidimeter and its server can be used for timely deployment, real-time data collection and rapid data assessment of surface water quality through use of public.

The nitrate sensor was based on colorimetric response of off-the-shelf nitrate testing strips. We have tested the nitrate range between 0 – 50 ppm.  The sensitivity showed a good linearity when the total color intensity (R+G+B) was taken with respect to different concentrations plotted.  While nitrate does occur naturally in groundwater, concentrations greater than 3 ppm generally indicate contamination.  The EPA has set a maximum contaminant level of 10 ppm nitrate-nitrogen for drinking water. Nitrate levels above this standard are considered potentially hazardous and can present significant health risks to humans.  Therefore, the developed prototype meter covers an enough range for this application.  The basic platform also has substantial potential to collect other water quality data based on optical sensing and data-knowledge projection through citizen-science based social media.

Sensors for turbitity, pH, and nitrate were developed.  The inexpensive sensors can be use by citizen science teams to assess and report water quality and quantity.  Therefore, the proposed work is expected to have broad effects by offering a platform and knowledge source for many areas of our societal needs including infrastructure management and water-related crisis response. Future work would include using two photodetectors and applying colorimetric approach which is supposed to negate out the potential artifacts from water coloration and ambient light for higher accuracy. Technology development is ongoing to advance this unique approach.
